column2: what strange novelties worthy of note I observed during the time of my abode there
column3: I will relate unto you. The first is
column4: that they are not begotten of women
column5: but of mankind: for they have no other marriage but of males: the name of women is utterly unknown among them: until they accomplish the age of five and twenty years
column6: they are given in marriage to others: from that time forwards they take others in marriage to themselves: for as soon as the infant is conceived the leg begins to swell
column7: and afterwards when the time of birth is come
column8: they give it a lance and take it out dead: then they lay it abroad with open mouth towards the wind
column9: and so it takes life: and I think thereof the Grecians call it the belly of the leg
column10: because therein they bear their children instead of a belly. I will tell you now of a thing more strange than this.
